questions.text: A 37-year-old male is struck by a car while walking at night. He is hemodynamically unstable at initial evaluation in the trauma bay. Advanced Trauma Life Support protocols are started, and an initial survey is completed. A chest radiograph and a pelvis AP radiograph (shown below) are obtained. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Immediate application of pelvic binder, continued resuscitation and re-evaluation of hemodynamic status
  • The patient has an Anterior-Posterior Compression type pelvic ring injury and this injury places the patient at risk of life-threatening hemorrhage.
  • The most appropriate next step in the trauma bay is to place the patient in a pelvic binder in order to minimize pelvic volume and impart stability to the injured hemipelvis. This will also cause tamponade of the bleeding pelvic veins, thereby preventing further internal blood loss.

Explanation of Other Options:

The patient should be taken directly to the OR for percutaneous placement of a pelvic external fixator (Option A): While this patient may need emergently to go to the OR for multiple reasons, the work-up needs to be completed; the patient's pelvis should be stabilized with a pelvic binder in the interim.

Obtain dedicated inlet and outlet pelvic views to better classify the fracture (Option B): These images should be obtained, but the pelvis must be compressed with a pelvic binder first.

Continue resuscitation and perform an immediate CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis (Option C): While the pelvis may not be the only bleeding source, it can be quickly stabilized with a pelvic binder; after binder placement, resuscitation and investigation of other bleeding sites should occur.

choices.text: Hilgenreiner's line - Baseline for measuring acetabular index
Shenton's line - Checks femoral neck-pelvic continuity
Perkins line - Localizes femoral head in developmental dysplasia of the hip
Acetabular index line - Measures acetabular roof slope

questions.text: Identify A in the image below and it's clinical use:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Perkins line is drawn vertically at the lateral margin of the acetabulum, perpendicular to Hilgenreiner's line, dividing the acetabular roof into medial and lateral quadrants.

  • Radiological features of DDH/CDH
  • In Von Rosen's view following parameters should be noted:
    • Perkin's Line: Vertical line drawn at the outer border of acetabulum
    • Hilgenreiner's line: Horizontal line drawn at the level of tri-radiate cartilage (Option A)
    • Shenton's line: Smooth curve formed by inferior border of neck of femur with superior margin of obturator foramen. (Option B)
    • Acetabular index: Normally is < 30° (Option C)
    • CE angle of Wiberg: Normal value is 15-30
  • Normally the head lies in the lower and inner quadrant formed by two lines (Perkin's & Hilgenreiner's). In DDH the head lies in outer & upper quadrant
  • In DDH In an older child, the following are the important X-ray findings:
    • Shenton's line is broken
    • Delayed appearance & retarded development of ossification of head of femur
    • Sloping acetabulum
    • Superior & lateral displacement of femoral head

Key Takeaways:

  • Perkins line is essential for quadrant-based localization of the femoral head in DDH screening.
  • Always combine with Hilgenreiner's line and acetabular index for comprehensive early hip dysplasia assessment.

questions.text: A 4-week-old female infant is referred for hip screening after a history of breech presentation. Examination reveals asymmetric thigh creases and a positive Ortolani click on the left. No other anomalies are noted. Which treatment device is most appropriate at this age?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The Pavlik harness is the first-line abduction orthosis for infants under six months with developmental dysplasia of the hip, maintaining hips in flexion and abduction to allow spontaneous reduction of the femoral head.

Pavlik Harness:

  • Abduction orthosis used in age group less than 6 months old child.
  • Splintage for Developmental dysplasia of hip
  • The most widely used device in management of developmental dysplasia of hip in Pavlik harness.
  • This device prevents adduction and extension while allowing further flexion, abduction and rotation. This position allows for gentle spontaneous reduction of dislocated hip.
  • Stretching of the tight adductors is also possible with the pawlik harness.
  • The device is worn full time till the hip stability is achieved

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the image
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Galeazzi test - The Galeazzi test, sometimes called Allis sign or Skyline test, is used to assess for hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip.
  • The test is performed with infant supine, hips flexed to 45° and knees flexed to 90° with feet flat on examining surface. Examiner looks for symmetry in the level of the knees. An inequality in the height of the knees is a positive Galeazzi sign and usually is caused by hip dislocation or congenital femoral shortening.
  • Barlow and Ortolani are done to assess whether hip is dislocatable or reducible respectively.
  • Trendelenburg test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism of hip joint.
  • Knee:

    • Anterior drawer's test - ACL injury
    • Lachmann's test - ACL injury
    • Posterior drawer's test - PCL injury
    • Mc Murray's test - Meniscal injury
    • Apley's grinding test - Meniscal injury
    • Adduction & abduction tests - Medial & lateral collateral ligament

questions.text: Investigation of choice for screening congenital dislocation of hip in an infant is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Investigations of Congenital Dislocation of Hip-
  • USG
  • Post-natal diagnosis within the first year is best made by an ultrasound
  • Allows assessment even in first two months when plain radiographs can be normal Considered as screening test of choice in case of CDH
  • X-Ray Plain films may be normal in first 2-3 months, however subtle changes begin to appear at 6 weeks
    • Reliable depiction of DDH made after 4-6 months
    • Most useful in period between 2-8 months
    • Classical findings: (putti's triad) 1. Absent or small proximal femoral capital epiphyses 2. Lateral displacement of femur 3. Shallow acetabulum with an increased inclination of acetabular roof > 30 degrees
    • Disruption of shenton's line
    • Head lies in outer and upper quadrant
  • CT Used for pre-surgical planning
  • MRI Considered as IOC/Best investigation for diagnosis of CDH

questions.text: An 8-year-old male presents with painless limp on examination and restricted abduction and internal rotation left hip. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Age, limp and restricted abduction and internal rotation, all go in favour of Perthes disease
  • PERTHES DISEASE:
    • AGE range - 4 to 8 years
    • Boys affected five times more commonly than girls.
    • Most common presenting complaint is limp. Classically, a painless limp is present but there may be pain during the periods of exacerbation. Second most common complaint is pain in the hip (may be referred to knee).
    • There is limitation of abduction and internal rotation in severe cases.

Explanation of Other Options:

CDH (Option A) presents in infancy or early childhood with hip instability on Ortolani/Barlow tests, not an isolated painless limp at age 8.

Tuberculous arthritis (Option B) usually causes chronic pain, night sweats, and restricted motion with systemic symptoms, not a painless limp.

Septic arthritis (Option C) presents acutely with severe pain, fever, and inability to bear weight, unlike the insidious limp of Perthes.

questions.text: A 13-year-old obese boy presents with a 3-month history of right groin pain and a limp that worsens with activity. On exam, his right hip is externally rotated and has limited internal rotation. An AP pelvis radiograph shows Trethowan's sign. Which condition is best diagnosed by this sign?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In SCFE, the capital femoral epiphysis slips posteriorly and inferiorly on the femoral neck, causing the "Klein's line" (Trethowan's sign) drawn along the superior femoral neck to miss the epiphysis.
  • Trethowan's sign is a sensitive early radiographic indicator of SCFE, even before obvious widening of the physis or epiphyseal displacement is seen.
  • Early detection allows prompt in situ fixation, which reduces slip progression and long-term complications.

Explanation of Other Options:

Perthes disease (Option A): Klein's line continues to intersect the intact epiphysis; radiographs show fragmentation and sclerosis of the femoral head instead.

DDH (Option B) is diagnosed on infant films with Hilgenreiner's, Perkins, and acetabular index measurements, not Trethowan's sign.

Fracture neck of femur (Option D) presents acutely with clear fracture lines through the neck; Klein's line is not used in acute fractures.

  • Perthes disease affects males mainly, ratio 5:1.

PERTHES DISEASE:

  • Also known as Coxa plana or Pseudocoxalgia
    • It is an osteochondritis of the epiphysis of the femoral head
    • The femoral head here becomes avascular → Avascular necrosis of femoral head
    • MC age group: 5-10 years
    • Boys affected five times more commonly than girls
    • The disease progress through 3 stages:
      • Stage of synovitis
      • Stage of trabecular necrosis
      • Stage of healing
    • Clinical picture:
      • Pain in hip, radiating to knee
      • Painless limp or hip stiffness
    • Upon examination:
      • Limb shortening
      • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation
    • X-ray:
      • Sclerosis of femoral head epiphysis
      • Hip joint space is increased
    • Treatment:
      • Head containment (by plaster, splint or surgical)-Head is kept inside the acetabulum while revascularisation takes place

questions.text: A 3-week-old female infant with a history of breech presentation is found to have a positive Barlow test during routine hip screening. Which condition does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • A positive Barlow test demonstrates that the femoral head can be dislocated posteriorly from the acetabulum, indicating hip instability consistent with developmental dysplasia.
  • Special tests designed for early detection of CDH are:
    1. Barlow test
    2. Ortolani test
  • Barlow test: Consists of 2 parts
    • 1st part: Hip & knee flexed & thighs gently adducted. Feel for abnormal posterior movement & sometimes dislocation with a distinct 'clink' of femoral head.
    • 2nd part: Thighs are gently abducted. If the hip was dislocated earlier, a distinct clink will be heard & felt indicating reduction of dislocated hip.

Ortolani's test:

Similar to 2nd part of Barlow's test. Hip & knee flexed and thighs gently abducted. A click of entrance will be felt as the femoral head slips back into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a painless limp. On examination, his Trendelenburg test is positive on the right side. He has a history of femoral neck nonunion. In which of the following conditions would you expect the Trendelenburg test to be negative despite a limp?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • Malunited shaft of femur does not produce a positive Trendelenburg test.
  • Trendelenburg test is a test for abductor mechanism of hip
  • Abductor mechanism is the mechanism which lifts the contralateral hip in swing phase of walking.
  • This mechanism is a First class lever where the fulcrum is in the center.
    • Fulcrum: Center of femoral head
    • Effort: Gluteus medius muscle
    • Load : Contralateral lower limb
    • Lever arm: Neck of femur
  • Any problem in the fulcrum/ effort/ lever arm will damage the abductor mechanism and give a positive Trendelenburg test. These are given in the table below.

Explanation for Answer:

  • Lover's fracture is an eponym for a calcaneal (heel) fracture, not an injury of the pelvic ring.

Crescent fracture (Option A) is a fracture of the posterior iliac wing that extends into the sacroiliac joint, seen in lateral compression pelvic injuries.

Straddle fracture (Option B): bilateral fractures of both the superior and inferior pubic rami, producing an unstable "straddle" pattern.

Duverney's fracture (Option C) is an isolated fracture of the iliac wing, disrupting one side of the pelvic ring but sparing the SI joint.

questions.text: A 75 year old woman fall in the bathroom and was unable to get up because of severe pain in the right hip. O/E there is tenderness in the greater trochanter and the hip is severely externally rotated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • Tenderness in the greater trochanter and severe external rotation of the hip is seen in intertrochanteric fracture of the hip.
  • These extracapsular fractures have a robust blood supply, allowing reliable union but requiring stable fixation (e.g., sliding hip screw) to restore alignment and enable early mobilization.
  • Distinguishing intertrochanteric from intracapsular neck fractures is critical, as the latter risk avascular necrosis and often necessitate arthroplasty in the elderly.
  • The differences between fracture neck of femur and intertrochanteric fracture is given below.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fracture neck of femur (Option A) presents with external rotation and shortening but without palpable trochanteric widening; tenderness is diffuse around the groin.

Hip dislocation (Option C) typically holds the limb in flexion and internal or external rotation depending on direction; radiographs confirm head position.

Fracture shaft of femur (Option D) causes thigh deformity and marked swelling mid-shaft, not isolated trochanteric tenderness.

questions.text: All are associated with dash board injury except
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • Patella fracture are not seen in dashboard injury. These are avulsion fractures that occur due to the excessive pull of the quadriceps during trauma.
  • Dashboard injuries occur when a flexed knee strikes the dashboard, transmitting force posteriorly through the femur to the hip and knee structures.
  • This mechanism classically produces posterior hip dislocation by driving the femoral head out of the acetabulum.
  • Simultaneously, the force on the proximal tibia often tears the posterior cruciate ligament or can dislocate the knee posteriorly, but does not directly fracture the patella.
  • Dash board injury can cause
    • Posterior dislocation of hip (Option A)
    • Posterior cruciate ligament injury (Option B)
    • Posterior dislocation of knee (Option D)

questions.text: Agnus Hunt traction is used for
questions.solution:
• Agnus Hunt traction is specifically designed to correct hip flexion contractures by applying a distal pull on the thigh while the knee remains extended, gradually extending the hip joint.
  • The system uses a skin traction strap on the anterior thigh and a counter-traction pad over the pelvis, avoiding knee flexion that would otherwise transfer forces to the knee.
  • It allows controlled, progressive stretching of posterior hip capsule and soft tissues, improving hip extension over days to weeks.
  • Other important tractions and their uses are given below
    • Dunlop traction - supracondylar fracture of humerus
    • Russel's traction - fracture shaft of femur
    • Gallow's traction - fracture shaft of femur in children
